text:
I'm running Tomcat4 under Windows 2000 with Java SDK 1.3.1. I am running it as 
an NT service using JavaService from Alexandria Software Consulting 
(http://www.alexandriasc.com/software/JavaService/index.html).

If I stop Tomcat, session objects should be serialized so 
a user can continue a session when Tomcat is restarted. If session objects 
exists when I stop Tomcat, I see a SESSIONS.ser file created in the work 
directory for my web application. However, the file is 0 bytes in size. Upon 
restart, I can't continue my session. On a coworkers Solaris box, we can start 
and stop Tomcat with sessions loaded from storage.

The localhost_log file contains some information that might be helpful. I 
believe the "Exception loading sessions from persistent storage" is related to 
Tomcat trying to read sessions from an empty .ser file. Here are the contents 
of my local_host log:

creator: garrel@more.net

text:
It would be helpful if you increased the level of debugging detail, by setting
the debug level on a <Manager> element nested inside a <Context> element for
your application:

  <Context path="/irequest" docBase="irequest">
    <Manager debug="99"/>
  </Context>

and then attempt to shut down and restart Tomcat.  It is important to report the
logs created when Tomcat is shut down (as well as when it is started up), since
that is where the problem is most likely to be occurring.
creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
remm@apache.org
text:
I successfully tested the feature under Win2k + JDK 1.3.0_02, using the simple 
sessions example from the "examples" webapp, and stopping/restarting Catalina.
The SESSIONS.ser is created in the work directory, and contains the appropriate 
serialized string objects.

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
Previously, any serialization or deserialization errors (such as trying to deal 
with a session attribute that does not implement Serializable) were being 
silently ignored, but it would abort writing the remainder of the sessions.  
Now, serialization and deserialization errors are logged (and the file closed), 
so problems should at least be reported in the log file. 

Could you try this with nightly build 20010717?

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
The original reporter kindly provided a test case that fails for him, but it
works for us on Solaris, Linux, and Windows.  Apparently, the problem is due to
the fact that they are starting and stopping Tomcat 4.0 using "JavaService" from
Alexandria Software:

http://www.alexandriasc.com/software/JavaService/download.html
